Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Novel Analysis Tools for Production of Higher Indican Yielding Plants for Bio-based Indigo
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impacts of this Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project relate to the increased viability of indigo as an agricultural crop competing with synthetically manufactured indigo dye. Indigo was among the major global cash crops of the 18th and 19th centuries and accounted for 100% of the indigo dye consumed in the world. Since the beginning of the 20th century, nearly 100% of the indigo dye consumed in the world has been synthetically manufactured from petroleum derivatives and hazardous and toxic chemicals. A small amount of plant-derived indigo dye is produced throughout the world using traditional artisan methods largely unchanged for centuries, but this supply is highly variable in purity and consistency and is far from cost competitive with synthetically manufactured indigo dye. Stony Creek Colors in cooperation with the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center seeks through this project to improve the available indigo planting stock by creating a high-throughput handheld assay device capable of rapid measurements of the chemical precursors for indigo which exist naturally in the plant leaves. During this process the team will also improve the understanding of the genetics of the existing indigo planting stock through DNA analysis of specific high-yielding plant varieties.

The technical objectives in this Phase I research project are to develop new tools, both genomic and phenomic, for analyzing the indigo crop Persicaria tinctoria, to produce an improved bio-based specialty chemical derived from renewable, abundant plant-material. The STTR project will map existing genetic resources while developing a unique approach for plant indican (indigo precursor) analysis which will enable non-destructive analysis of plant leaves in breeding lines. Finally, a genetic mapping population between high and low indican-producing parent plants will be constructed for analysis and laboratory validation. Successful completion of the Phase I tasks tied to these objectives will prove the feasibility of selecting and maintaining high indigotin yielding strains of P. tinctoria. These improvements will be commercialized through higher indigotin yielding breeders seed stock and will be spread to over 26,000 acres of cropland in the Southeast US within 6 years, resulting in a more reliable and cost-competitive bio-based indigo dye extracted from U.S. grown plant material. This will allow plant-derived indigo to be more cost-competitive with synthetic indigo dye and to meet the immediate market demand for U.S. bio-based indigo by denim mills.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Stony Creek Colors sells clean and safe natural dyes to the textile and fashion industries, allowing its customers to offer environmentally conscious premium products.  Through its flagship natural indigo product, the company has developed and proven a complete agricultural supply chain to replace synthetic dyes with plant-based drop-in solutions.  Innovations across the complete crop and processing value chain allow Stony Creek to sustainably produce plant-based dyes with full transparency and authenticity, meeting the technical performance and volume requirements of textile mills and fashion brands worldwide without compromising product integrity.   Natural indigo dye was once a driver of global economics, sourced from three different families of indigo-bearing plants, cultivated across roughly 2,700 square miles of cropland on five continents.  However global production ultimately fell to trivial levels following the development by Baeyer and ultimately BASF of an industrially viable route to synthetic indigo in the early twentieth century. 

As a result, roughly 100 years of crop development and agronomic improvements had been lost by the time Stony Creek Colors began sourcing its seedstock from global seed banks and repositories of the historic varietal accessions.  The company grows three species of indigo-bearing plants for its dye production activities, and in 2016 managed 150 acres of indigo cropland.  Phenotypic variation within each of the varieties is visually observed to be high, and the resulting performance of each likewise varies across such important factors as indigo dye yield, biomass regrowth rates, temperature and drought tolerance, seed germination rates, and resistance to herbicides.  In order more better assess in-field performance of indigo plant varieties and intentional or natural hybridization among accessions with notable traits, Stony Creek Colors sought through this project to develop a method for rapidly assaying indigo plants for in-vivo levels of indigo’s chemical precursor and to tie that information to a genetic mapping of the company’s highest performing Japanese indigo (Persicaria tinctoria) variety.  

Through this research, Stony Creek Colors was able to develop and validate a method for rapidly assessing the precursor content within the leaves of various indigo-bearing plants utilizing fluorescence spectroscopy.  This will ultimately allow farmers to quickly assay large crop populations in the field for the purposes of both refining the genetic stock through selective or non-selective crossing, as well as the more tactical result of assessing the harvest-readiness of a crop.  This tool has also already proven valuable in monitoring and characterizing in-leaf and in-reactor conversion of the glucoside precursor to indoxyl and ultimately to indigo, and has supported enzyme research informing new production processes.  Additionally, the company was able to assemble 1.2 Gbp of an estimated 3.2Gbp genome sequence for Stony Creek Colors’ high-performing P. tinctoria variety which will be used as a starting point for predicting genetics-driven performance of the company’s P. tinctoria stock and future crosses. 

These research developments are each critical in advancing natural indigo as both a specialty crop and a bio-based product, as well as returning value to both the manufacturer and the small- and mid-sized farmers.  Compared to traditional high-value agricultural crops, indigo has missed out on roughly one-hundred years of crop development, field operations, and chemical processing advancements.  The ability to rapidly move indigo production crops from a highly-variable, near-wild population to a selectively bred subset pursuing both high dye yield and agronomic efficiency and robustness will serve to increase farmer yields and revenues while enabling natural indigo to be competitive with its synthetic counterpart in the commercial market.
